description: Unknown, possibly from obsolete Middle English gawren (“to stare”) which is of uncertain origin, probably from Old Norse gá (“to watch, heed”) or gaurr (“rough fellow”) (Proto-Indo-European *gʰow-rós, from *gʰew- (“to be angry”)). Compare with English gaw.

adjectives.description: garish (comparative more garish, superlative most garish)

entries.meaning: Overly ostentatious; so colourful as to be in bad taste. [from 1540s]
examples: The dress fits her well, but the pattern is rather garish.
